In the current segment [1-2], the man in black shorts is seen pressing his hands on the dog and moving his mouth. The dog turns its head to look at the man, moves its body, and then the man pushes the dog to the lower right corner with both hands and stands up. 

Earlier, in the previous segment [0-1], the dog was sitting with its head turned to the left. There was no indication of movement or change in direction in that frame. The dog remained stationary.

In the current segment, the dog turns its head to look at the man and then moves its body. This indicates a change in direction as the dog shifts its focus and position. The man then pushes the dog to the lower right corner, which is another change in direction.

Given these observations, the dog has changed its direction of movement at least once in the current segment. This aligns with the option One time(D). However, considering the previous segment where the dog was stationary, the total number of direction changes observed so far is one.

Earlier, in the previous segment [1-2], the man pushed the dog to the lower right corner, and the dog turned its head to look at the man and moved its body. This indicates a change in direction as the dog shifted its focus and position.

In the current segment, the dog follows the man to the left, which is another change in direction. 

Given these observations, the dog has changed its direction of movement at least twice: once when it was pushed to the lower right corner and again when it followed the man to the left. This aligns with the option Two times(A).

Therefore, the most appropriate answer is A (Two times).
